text:
I will. I am writing in a section of a proposal why we should use Julia, and I guess if I can make a good argumentation it will help. 

Currently I have these points in mind:
Empiricists use dynamic languaged (R, Python) whereas modelers use Fortran... This is one of the barrier to collaboration between these two groups, using Julia would solve it. 

Another thing, related, is that ESM are going to be more and more modular, and if empiricists use same language as modelers, it will make the implementation of new modules much easier. 

I don't know what are the machine learning libraries in C, but I believe Julia is at least more active? 

Julia is optimal for GPU and supercomputers 

I don't see what is the compromise we would make, what is the argument to use C? What is better with C?

Also, as we aim for transparency and open source, Julia dynamic language is much easier to read and I believe would attract more attention

text: It would be nice if the people at CLIMA could write a blogpost with their experience so far. CLIMA is a great experiment that we in the community could leverage a lot but the last things I saw were the news from when the initiative was launched. I wish I could have something to show during my Julia preaching here (I am in an Atmospheric Science group).
